news_header: Scotland faces a significant plastic pollution problem at Arrochar, with 62,000 items washing up annually. A proposed deposit return scheme aims to reduce waste, but political delays have pushed the implementation date to 2027.
news_original_title: Scenic loch becomes magnet for Scotland's plastic waste
news_text: At Loch Long in Argyll, Scotland, a major plastic pollution issue arises, with around 62,000 items of litter washing ashore each year, primarily from Glasgow's waterways. Local residents struggle to clean the waste, much of which is entangled in seaweed. Campaigners advocate for a deposit return scheme for bottles and cans to prevent waste from entering water bodies. Although a Scottish scheme was initially set for 2023, it faced delays due to business objections and UK government considerations for a unified scheme. The target date has now been pushed to 2027. Meanwhile, Ireland's successful deposit return scheme has shown positive results, capturing nearly a billion items in its first year. Scottish officials hope to boost recycling rates and reduce littering through the new scheme, with a commitment to implement it by 2027.
